elements.content: Birefringent crystals with optical anisotropy, which are employed to modulate the polarization of light, play a vital role in many fields of the optical industry. In this Communication, two mixed alkali metal hydroisocyanurates, RbLi­(H2C3N3O3)2·2H2O (I) and CsLi­(H2C3N3O3)2·2H2O (II), were synthesized by a simple aqueous solution method, and they feature layered structures composed of ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]− ribbons through hydrogen bonds with the separation of water molecules and alkali cations. They exhibit a simultaneously short ultraviolet cutoff and giant birefringence, resulting from the perfect parallel alignment of π-conjugated (H2C3N3O3)− anions. Interestingly, the first-principles calculations elucidated that the electronic states and optical properties are slightly different owing to the distinct p−π interaction between alkaline metals and the (H2C3N3O3)− group despite the isostructural crystallographic lattice.
elements.clean_text: Birefringent crystals with optical anisotropy, which are employed to modulate the polarization of light, play a vital role in many fields of the optical industry. In this Communication, two mixed alkali metal hydroisocyanurates, RbLi(H2C3N3O3)2⋅2H2O (I) and CsLi(H2C3N3O3)2⋅2H2O (II), were synthesized by a simple aqueous solution method, and they feature layered structures composed of ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]- ribbons through hydrogen bonds with the separation of water molecules and alkali cations. They exhibit a simultaneously short ultraviolet cutoff and giant birefringence, resulting from the perfect parallel alignment of π-conjugated (H2C3N3O3)- anions. Interestingly, the first-principles calculations elucidated that the electronic states and optical properties are slightly different owing to the distinct p-π interaction between alkaline metals and the (H2C3N3O3)- group despite the isostructural crystallographic lattice.

elements.content:
Two new hydroisocyanurates, CsLi­(H2C3N3O3)2·2H2O and RbLi­(H2C3N3O3)2·2H2O, with wide ultraviolet transparency and strong optical anisotropy were reported.

Ultraviolet (UV) birefringent crystals with strong optical anisotropy are crucial parts of the modern optical communication system and laser modulators. For a long time, commercial UV birefringent crystals have been available, such as fluoride MgF2, carbonate CaCO3, and borate α-BaB2O4. However, some intrinsic drawbacks limit their wide application due to small optical anisotropy or low UV transmission. For example, the birefringence of the MgF2 crystal is too small (only 0.013 at 254 nm). Natural CaCO3 with high optical quality is scarce in nature, and its artificial growth is very difficult, whereas the α-BaB2O4 crystal suffers a structural phase transition at 925 °C and tends to crack during the growth process. Therefore, it is an urgently developing field to discover new UV birefringent crystals with high performance.
elements.clean_text:
Two new hydroisocyanurates, CsLi(H2C3N3O3)2⋅2H2O and RbLi(H2C3N3O3)2⋅2H2O, with wide ultraviolet transparency and strong optical anisotropy were reported.

Ultraviolet (UV) birefringent crystals with strong optical anisotropy are crucial parts of the modern optical communication system and laser modulators. For a long time, commercial UV birefringent crystals have been available, such as fluoride MgF2, carbonate CaCO3, and borate α-BaB2O4. However, some intrinsic drawbacks limit their wide application due to small optical anisotropy or low UV transmission. For example, the birefringence of the MgF2 crystal is too small (only 0.013 at 254 nm). Natural CaCO3 with high optical quality is scarce in nature, and its artificial growth is very difficult, whereas the α-BaB2O4 crystal suffers a structural phase transition at 925 °C and tends to crack during the growth process. Therefore, it is an urgently developing field to discover new UV birefringent crystals with high performance.

elements.content: In general, the optical response of a crystal is determined by its crystal structure and constituent anions and cations. For example, the planar π-conjugated (B3O6)3– groups exhibit stronger optical anisotropy than the tetrahedral (BO4)5– groups. As a result, the birefringence of the α-BaB2O4 (0.106) crystal is two orders of magnitude higher than that of the SrB4O7 crystal (0.003). On the contrary, the influence of metal cations on refractive indices and birefringence was also studied in our previous works. For instance, the birefringence of ABe2BO3F2 (A = K, Rb, Cs) crystal gradually reduces with the increasing radius of alkali metals and decreasing density of (BO3)3– groups, namely, the volume effect. Also, a similar molecular engineering strategy is applied in AB4O6F (A = NH4, Na, K, Rb, Cs, K0.5Cs0.5) and M2B10O14F6 (M = Ca, Sr). Consequently, it is an attractive task to regulate the optical anisotropy of crystal quantitatively, by rational molecular design and atom selection.
elements.clean_text: In general, the optical response of a crystal is determined by its crystal structure and constituent anions and cations. For example, the planar π-conjugated (B3O6)3- groups exhibit stronger optical anisotropy than the tetrahedral (BO4)5- groups. As a result, the birefringence of the α-BaB2O4 (0.106) crystal is two orders of magnitude higher than that of the SrB4O7 crystal (0.003). On the contrary, the influence of metal cations on refractive indices and birefringence was also studied in our previous works. For instance, the birefringence of ABe2BO3F2 (A = K, Rb, Cs) crystal gradually reduces with the increasing radius of alkali metals and decreasing density of (BO3)3- groups, namely, the volume effect. Also, a similar molecular engineering strategy is applied in AB4O6F (A = NH4, Na, K, Rb, Cs, K0.5Cs0.5) and M2B10O14F6 (M = Ca, Sr). Consequently, it is an attractive task to regulate the optical anisotropy of crystal quantitatively, by rational molecular design and atom selection.

elements.content: Cyanurates or hydroisocyanurates containing π-conjugated (H x C3N3O3) x−3 (x = 0–3) anions have gained much interest since the advent of nonlinear optical crystals M3(C3N3O3)2 (M = Ca, Sr) with very strong second-harmonic generation (SHG) responses in Meyer’s group. It is noteworthy that the (C3N3O3)3– anion is isoelectric to the (B3O6)3– group but shows much larger anisotropic polarization (birefringence) and SHG susceptibilities than those of borate analogues due to the enhanced pπ –pπ conjugated interaction and the additional p z electron on C atoms. Accordingly, several cyanurates or hydroisocyanurates with strong optical anisotropy were found, such as centrosymmetric Ba2M­(C3N3O3)2 (M = Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, and Pb), K2(HC3N3O3) and noncentrosymmetric KLi­(HC3N3O3)·2H2O, Cs3Na­(H2C3N3O3)4·3H2O, and so on. In particular, the optical anisotropy (Δn = 0.35 at 800 nm) of Ba2M­(C3N3O3)2 is almost three times larger than that of isomorphic Ba2M­(B3O6)2 (Δn = 0.11) at the same wavelength. Furthermore, benefiting from the large electronegativity difference between C (χp = 2.55) and O­(χp = 3.44)/N­(χp = 3.04), the (H x C3N3O3) x−3 anions have a wide molecular band gap and sufficient UV transparency. As a result, these groups should be excellent constructing blocks for UV birefringent crystals.
elements.clean_text: Cyanurates or hydroisocyanurates containing π-conjugated (H x C3N3O3) x-3 (x = 0-3) anions have gained much interest since the advent of nonlinear optical crystals M3(C3N3O3)2 (M = Ca, Sr) with very strong second-harmonic generation (SHG) responses in Meyer's group. It is noteworthy that the (C3N3O3)3- anion is isoelectric to the (B3O6)3- group but shows much larger anisotropic polarization (birefringence) and SHG susceptibilities than those of borate analogues due to the enhanced pπ -pπ conjugated interaction and the additional p z  electron on C atoms. Accordingly, several cyanurates or hydroisocyanurates with strong optical anisotropy were found, such as centrosymmetric Ba2M(C3N3O3)2 (M = Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, and Pb), K2(HC3N3O3) and noncentrosymmetric KLi(HC3N3O3)⋅2H2O, Cs3Na(H2C3N3O3)4⋅3H2O, and so on. In particular, the optical anisotropy (Δn = 0.35 at 800 nm) of Ba2M(C3N3O3)2 is almost three times larger than that of isomorphic Ba2M(B3O6)2 (Δn = 0.11) at the same wavelength. Furthermore, benefiting from the large electronegativity difference between C (χp = 2.55) and O(χp = 3.44)/N(χp = 3.04), the (H x C3N3O3) x-3 anions have a wide molecular band gap and sufficient UV transparency. As a result, these groups should be excellent constructing blocks for UV birefringent crystals.

elements.content: As previously mentioned, the key point in birefringent crystal engineering is how to align functional anionic groups in a perfectly parallel manner to give the maximum improvement rather than a negative contribution. As we have seen, there is no detailed exploration on this subject in metal cyanurates and hydroisocyanurates. In this Communication, we single out the small cation with a basal plane in the LiO4 tetrahedra to align the ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]− ribbons and enhance the optical anisotropy of hydroisocyanurates. Two isostructural mixed alkali metal hydroisocyanurates, RbLi­(H2C3N3O3)2·2H2O (I) and CsLi­(H2C3N3O3)2·2H2O (II), were grown, and their crystal structures and thermal and optical properties were studied by combining experimental characterization and theoretical calculations. A distinct p−π interaction was proposed in II for the first time, and its influence on linear refractive indices was also elucidated.
elements.clean_text: As previously mentioned, the key point in birefringent crystal engineering is how to align functional anionic groups in a perfectly parallel manner to give the maximum improvement rather than a negative contribution. As we have seen, there is no detailed exploration on this subject in metal cyanurates and hydroisocyanurates. In this Communication, we single out the small cation with a basal plane in the LiO4 tetrahedra to align the ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]- ribbons and enhance the optical anisotropy of hydroisocyanurates. Two isostructural mixed alkali metal hydroisocyanurates, RbLi(H2C3N3O3)2⋅2H2O (I) and CsLi(H2C3N3O3)2⋅2H2O (II), were grown, and their crystal structures and thermal and optical properties were studied by combining experimental characterization and theoretical calculations. A distinct p-π interaction was proposed in II for the first time, and its influence on linear refractive indices was also elucidated.

elements.content: Both I and II crystallize in monoclinic space group P21 /m, and only I is selected to describe the structure. I features a quasi-2D layered structure built from ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]− ribbons separated by water molecules and Li+ and Rb+ cations (a). All of the ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]− ribbons present a completely reversed parallel arrangement along the b axis (b). The ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]− ribbons are composed of planar basic building groups of π-conjugated six-membered-ring (6-MR) (H2C3N3O3)− anions that further are connected via two strong hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygen atoms and protonated nitrogen atoms of two neighboring anionic units. In the 6-MR (H2C3N3O3)− group, the average bond lengths for C–O and C–N are 1.23 and 1.36 Å, respectively. Li atoms are surrounded by four oxygen atoms in generating the LiO4 tetrahedra, with the Li–O bond lengths covering from 1.90 to 1.97 Å. The ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]− ribbons are further linked by the apical O atoms from LiO4 tetrahedra, resulting in a coplanar parallel arrangement along the b axis (c,d). Rb coordinates to eight O atoms and two N atoms, forming a distorted polyhedron with a Rb–O/N bond distance of 2.87 to 3.46 Å (e).
elements.clean_text: Both I and II crystallize in monoclinic space group P21 /m, and only I is selected to describe the structure. I features a quasi-2D layered structure built from ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]- ribbons separated by water molecules and Li+ and Rb+ cations (a). All of the ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]- ribbons present a completely reversed parallel arrangement along the b axis (b). The ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]- ribbons are composed of planar basic building groups of π-conjugated six-membered-ring (6-MR) (H2C3N3O3)- anions that further are connected via two strong hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygen atoms and protonated nitrogen atoms of two neighboring anionic units. In the 6-MR (H2C3N3O3)- group, the average bond lengths for C-O and C-N are 1.23 and 1.36 Å, respectively. Li atoms are surrounded by four oxygen atoms in generating the LiO4 tetrahedra, with the Li-O bond lengths covering from 1.90 to 1.97 Å. The ∞ 2[H2C3N3O3]- ribbons are further linked by the apical O atoms from LiO4 tetrahedra, resulting in a coplanar parallel arrangement along the b axis (c,d). Rb coordinates to eight O atoms and two N atoms, forming a distorted polyhedron with a Rb-O/N bond distance of 2.87 to 3.46 Å (e).

elements.content: (a) Unit cell of I along [001]. (b) Arrangement of monobasic isocyanurate (H2C3N3O3)− anions. (c) Parallel coplanar alignment of (H2C3N3O3)− ribbons interlinked via O atoms from LiO4 tetrahedra. (d,e) Coordination environment of Li and Rb atoms.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Unit cell of I along [001]. (b) Arrangement of monobasic isocyanurate (H2C3N3O3)- anions. (c) Parallel coplanar alignment of (H2C3N3O3)- ribbons interlinked via O atoms from LiO4 tetrahedra. (d,e) Coordination environment of Li and Rb atoms.

elements.content: The as-grown crystals from facile aqueous solution exhibit colorless block-like shapes (Figure S1), and the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy is applied to explore the distribution of elements (Figure S2). Their powder X-ray diffraction data prepared from heating aqueous solutions of mixtures of H3C3N3O3, Li2CO3, and Rb2CO3/Cs2CO3 were collected at room temperature, and they are in good agreement with the calculated patterns (Figure S3). The single crystals with good crystallinity were successfully grown through a simple aqueous solution method, indicating the easiness of crystal acquisition for further research. The vibration modes of the isocyanurate anions were detected by the infrared (IR) spectra. As described in Figure S4, 428 and 692 cm–1 are derived from the bending vibration of NCO and CNC bonds. The bands at 470 and 555 cm–1 should be attributed to the vibrations of CO. 867 and 976 cm–1 are probably due to the asymmetrical stretching vibration of the C3N3 groups. The peaks at 1079, 1386, and 1259 cm–1 can be seen as belonging to the stretching vibrations of C–O and C–N bonds and the bending vibration of N–H bonds. The wavenumbers of all of the peaks are essentially in good agreement with the vibrational modes in Cs­[H2C3N3O3]·0.5H2O and Na­[H2C3N3O3]·H2O. The thermal analysis implemented for I and II displays two key steps of mass loss from the thermal gravimetric (TG) measurements (Figure S5). The mass losses of 9.3 and 8.4% in the temperature range from 150 to 350 °C are assigned to the absence of two crystal water molecules per formula for I and II, respectively. The second step starts at ∼350 °C and ends at ∼600 °C, and it accounts for the largest part of the mass loss of about 45.1 and 40.2% for I and II, respectively, which is compatible with the calculated values of 44.8 and 39.8%, as related to the decomposition of (H2C3N3O3)− units.
elements.clean_text: The as-grown crystals from facile aqueous solution exhibit colorless block-like shapes (Figure S1), and the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy is applied to explore the distribution of elements (Figure S2). Their powder X-ray diffraction data prepared from heating aqueous solutions of mixtures of H3C3N3O3, Li2CO3, and Rb2CO3/Cs2CO3 were collected at room temperature, and they are in good agreement with the calculated patterns (Figure S3). The single crystals with good crystallinity were successfully grown through a simple aqueous solution method, indicating the easiness of crystal acquisition for further research. The vibration modes of the isocyanurate anions were detected by the infrared (IR) spectra. As described in Figure S4, 428 and 692 cm-1 are derived from the bending vibration of NCO and CNC bonds. The bands at 470 and 555 cm-1 should be attributed to the vibrations of CO. 867 and 976 cm-1 are probably due to the asymmetrical stretching vibration of the C3N3 groups. The peaks at 1079, 1386, and 1259 cm-1 can be seen as belonging to the stretching vibrations of C-O and C-N bonds and the bending vibration of N-H bonds. The wavenumbers of all of the peaks are essentially in good agreement with the vibrational modes in Cs[H2C3N3O3]⋅0.5H2O and Na[H2C3N3O3]⋅H2O. The thermal analysis implemented for I and II displays two key steps of mass loss from the thermal gravimetric (TG) measurements (Figure S5). The mass losses of 9.3 and 8.4% in the temperature range from 150 to 350 °C are assigned to the absence of two crystal water molecules per formula for I and II, respectively. The second step starts at ~350 °C and ends at ~600 °C, and it accounts for the largest part of the mass loss of about 45.1 and 40.2% for I and II, respectively, which is compatible with the calculated values of 44.8 and 39.8%, as related to the decomposition of (H2C3N3O3)- units.

elements.content: According to UV–vis–NIR diffuse reflectance spectra, the experimental band gap values of I and II are obtained as 5.16 and 5.12 eV (), which are comparable to those of Cs3Na­(H2C3N3O3)4·3H2O (5.46 eV) and KLHCY (5.23 eV). Their corresponding UV absorption edges are about 240 and 242 nm for I and II, respectively. They also possess a transmittance of up to 80% in the range of 250–1200 nm and have a wide transparency window ranging from near-IR to UV spectral regions.
elements.clean_text: According to UV-vis-NIR diffuse reflectance spectra, the experimental band gap values of I and II are obtained as 5.16 and 5.12 eV (), which are comparable to those of Cs3Na(H2C3N3O3)4⋅3H2O (5.46 eV) and KLHCY (5.23 eV). Their corresponding UV absorption edges are about 240 and 242 nm for I and II, respectively. They also possess a transmittance of up to 80% in the range of 250-1200 nm and have a wide transparency window ranging from near-IR to UV spectral regions.

elements.content: Band gaps for (a) I and (b) II.
elements.clean_text: 2  Band gaps for (a) I and (b) II.

elements.content: Despite the same crystal structures and similar band gaps, the electronic states of I and II are still different, in principle. The electronic band (Figure S6) positions and dispersions of two compounds are nearly same, with a wide band gap of >4 eV. Their DOS intensities () are also comparable, except for the divergent positions of Rb 4p (E = −9 eV) and Cs 5p (E = −6 eV) orbitals. The position of Cs 5p matches well with that of conjugated π orbitals (yellow region in a,b) from (H2C3N3O3)− anionic groups. As shown in c,d, this region in I contains only π orbitals, whereas that in II is simultaneously composed of π orbitals and Cs 5p orbitals, thus indicating that there are strong p−π interaction between Cs and (H2C3N3O3)− groups. In contrast with the p–π* interaction defined in the unoccupied conduction band between Pb 6p and anti-π orbitals, this p−π interaction is defined in the occupied valence band between Cs 5p and bonded π orbitals. As for the p−π* interaction, it can also exist between Sn 5p, Sb 5p, Bi 6p, and the cyanurate group. However, the p−π interaction is different. The position of np orbitals of alkali metals and alkali-earth metals is relatively constant, and it usually follows the common trend Na 2p (−20 eV) < K 3p (−11 eV) < Rb 4p (−8 eV) < Cs 5p (−6 eV) and Mg 2p (−40 eV) < Ca 3p (−18 eV) < Sr 4p (−14 eV) < Ba 5p (−10 eV). Accordingly, this kind of p−π interaction occurs only in Cs-containing compounds. In our previous report of Cs3Na­(H2C3N3O3)4·3H2O, this effect is also present and is further enhanced owing to the shortened Cs–O/Cs–N bond (3.136/3.319 Å) compared with that in I (3.344/3.517 Å). We believe this p−π interaction is a general condition in other systems, such as carbonates, nitrites, and borates. However, owing to the reduced conjugated interaction in triangular (BO3)3–, (CO3)2–, and (NO3)− units, the interacting strength would also consequently weaken.
elements.clean_text: Despite the same crystal structures and similar band gaps, the electronic states of I and II are still different, in principle. The electronic band (Figure S6) positions and dispersions of two compounds are nearly same, with a wide band gap of >4 eV. Their DOS intensities () are also comparable, except for the divergent positions of Rb 4p (E = -9 eV) and Cs 5p (E = -6 eV) orbitals. The position of Cs 5p matches well with that of conjugated π orbitals (yellow region in a,b) from (H2C3N3O3)- anionic groups. As shown in c,d, this region in I contains only π orbitals, whereas that in II is simultaneously composed of π orbitals and Cs 5p orbitals, thus indicating that there are strong p-π interaction between Cs and (H2C3N3O3)- groups. In contrast with the p-π* interaction defined in the unoccupied conduction band between Pb 6p and anti-π orbitals, this p-π interaction is defined in the occupied valence band between Cs 5p and bonded π orbitals. As for the p-π* interaction, it can also exist between Sn 5p, Sb 5p, Bi 6p, and the cyanurate group. However, the p-π interaction is different. The position of np orbitals of alkali metals and alkali-earth metals is relatively constant, and it usually follows the common trend Na 2p (-20 eV) < K 3p (-11 eV) < Rb 4p (-8 eV) < Cs 5p (-6 eV) and Mg 2p (-40 eV) < Ca 3p (-18 eV) < Sr 4p (-14 eV) < Ba 5p (-10 eV). Accordingly, this kind of p-π interaction occurs only in Cs-containing compounds. In our previous report of Cs3Na(H2C3N3O3)4⋅3H2O, this effect is also present and is further enhanced owing to the shortened Cs-O/Cs-N bond (3.136/3.319 Å) compared with that in I (3.344/3.517 Å). We believe this p-π interaction is a general condition in other systems, such as carbonates, nitrites, and borates. However, owing to the reduced conjugated interaction in triangular (BO3)3-, (CO3)2-, and (NO3)- units, the interacting strength would also consequently weaken.

elements.content: Partial density of states (DOS) projected constituent atoms of (a) I and (b) II. The yellow region represents the occupied conjugated π orbitals ranging from −6.2 to −5.9 eV of (c) I and (d) II.
elements.clean_text: 3  Partial density of states (DOS) projected constituent atoms of (a) I and (b) II. The yellow region represents the occupied conjugated π orbitals ranging from -6.2 to -5.9 eV of (c) I and (d) II.

elements.content: Next, the emerging question is how this p−π interaction affects the optical properties of the title compounds. On the basis of the calculated band structure, we studied their linear optical response. Both of them exhibit strong optical anisotropy with a birefringence of >0.30 along the b and c axes (). As for the detailed comparison of refractive indices along three crystalline axes, the n 100 values are nearly the same in I and II, but the n 010 and n 100 values are slightly higher in II. In particular, the n 100 value of II increases by 0.012. This improvement can be attributed to two reasons: largely polarized Cs atoms as well as a strong p−π interaction. The first factor is from the volume effect, as demonstrated in KBBF family crystals, and the second factor is proposed in this work for the first time. Moreover, the turning point between n 100 and n 010 is also blue-shifted from 300 nm in I to 292 nm in II. Combining the short UV transparent wavelength and the large birefringence, I and II are both promising UV birefringent crystals.
elements.clean_text: Next, the emerging question is how this p-π interaction affects the optical properties of the title compounds. On the basis of the calculated band structure, we studied their linear optical response. Both of them exhibit strong optical anisotropy with a birefringence of >0.30 along the b and c axes (). As for the detailed comparison of refractive indices along three crystalline axes, the n 100 values are nearly the same in I and II, but the n 010 and n 100 values are slightly higher in II. In particular, the n 100 value of II increases by 0.012. This improvement can be attributed to two reasons: largely polarized Cs atoms as well as a strong p-π interaction. The first factor is from the volume effect, as demonstrated in KBBF family crystals, and the second factor is proposed in this work for the first time. Moreover, the turning point between n 100 and n 010 is also blue-shifted from 300 nm in I to 292 nm in II. Combining the short UV transparent wavelength and the large birefringence, I and II are both promising UV birefringent crystals.

elements.content: Calculated refractive dispersion indices in (a) I and (b) II.

elements.content: In summary, two mixed alkali metal monobasic isocyanurate salts ALi­(H2C3N3O3)2·2H2O (A = Rb, Cs) with high UV transparency were successfully synthesized by an aqueous solution method. The first-principles calculations demonstrate their strong optical anisotropy and the distinct p−π interaction in Cs 5p and (H2C3N3O3)− π orbitals. This intriguing case will provide some new inspiration for the rational design of optoelectronic functional materials containing conjugated groups and alkali metals. Furthermore, the C3N3O3-based compounds possess infinite possibilities, just like a magic box, as excellent nonlinear optical or birefringent materials. We believe that they will be a mainstream research trend and reach a climax in the near future.
elements.clean_text: In summary, two mixed alkali metal monobasic isocyanurate salts ALi(H2C3N3O3)2⋅2H2O (A = Rb, Cs) with high UV transparency were successfully synthesized by an aqueous solution method. The first-principles calculations demonstrate their strong optical anisotropy and the distinct p-π interaction in Cs 5p and (H2C3N3O3)- π orbitals. This intriguing case will provide some new inspiration for the rational design of optoelectronic functional materials containing conjugated groups and alkali metals. Furthermore, the C3N3O3-based compounds possess infinite possibilities, just like a magic box, as excellent nonlinear optical or birefringent materials. We believe that they will be a mainstream research trend and reach a climax in the near future.

They also possess a transmittance of up to 80% in the range of 250-1200 nm and have a wide transparency window ranging from near-IR to UV spectral regions.
